text: Essentially the majority of women needing an abortion in Australia still need to find around $400 to $700 cash. That is a scandal IMHO.
author: samanthamaiden

text: Fair enough re Marie Stopes wanting to get money back but women shouldn’t be paying that much to access a medical abortion (that’s not the morning after pill by the way that’s a different thing)
author: samanthamaiden

text: Secondly because @mariestopesaus invested a bomb to get the drug into Australia they are charging too much for it, I believe, to get their money back and cross subsidise other projects. They also invested a lot in GP training
author: samanthamaiden

text: It’s because the whole area is largely privatised really. Women are also paying out of pocket for ultrasounds to determine pregnancy and after with RU486 plus management fee for GPS. That could all be addressed through Medicare I think
author: samanthamaiden

text: Nope
author: samanthamaiden

text: Also read my chapter in the book! Haha
author: samanthamaiden

text: Actually this one better explaining cost
author: samanthamaiden

text: This is long overdue. For too long governments have not tackled fact that cost is now biggest barrier to women accessing abortion, not decriminalisation, although Labor is promising to tackle that too. If you want an example of a story that really impacts readers this is it. END
author: samanthamaiden

text: In short, media outlets have dropped the ball a bit on this announcement IMHO. Once again are not noticing how big and in some cases radical policies Labor is proposing if it wins office.
author: samanthamaiden

text: Plan to link Commonwealth funding to public hospitals offering abortions is a huge announcement. Controversial too, it’s a bold policy & how this isn’t on the front page of every newspaper in country I have no idea. Can only be because of male editors or squeamish female ones
author: samanthamaiden

text: The cost of RU486 - the abortion pill is a national scandal. It’s available for $40 on the PBS. - or less with a concessions card but women are getting whacked up to $600 to access it out of pocket. I’ve written about this for years and also in this new book
author: samanthamaiden

text: However there’s cost barriers to these long lasting contraceptives that ALP wIll also pursue through a review of Medicare rebates
author: samanthamaiden

text: Moving on the long acting contraception options like IUDS and implants - Australia’s use is woefully low by international standards. Only 10 per cent of Oz women use long acting contraceptives . In the UK it’s triple that number. IUDs are set and forget &can last for 5 years
author: samanthamaiden

text: Starting with the contraceptive pill - perhaps this is a better news lead for some outlets - women would secure scripts for pill for up to 3 years - which already happens in NZ. That’s a huge change which will save millions of women unnecessary and expensive trips to the GP
author: samanthamaiden

text: It’s bad news judgement not to give this story the run it deserves - there are 12 million women in Australia and the vast majority of those women will use contraception and in some cases access pregnancy termination services at some point in their lives
author: samanthamaiden

text: This announcement is big news - a substantial attempt to tackle women’s access to affordable and accessible contraception and abortion. But you wouldn’t know that picking up a newspaper today where the story is buried or not reported at all
author: samanthamaiden

text: Little thread on news judgement and stories on women’s health that don’t get anywhere near attention they deserve - including today when this story affecting millions of female readers gets less coverage than locking up a few dozen “dangerous boat people” on Christmas Island
author: samanthamaiden

text: I think that’s true actually

text: Yes. But I just make the point it needs to be reported in that way rather than saying he's shifted his language because I don't think he has. I agree it's frustrating but I just try and accurately report what he's actually saying while obviously making point of what is implied
